reviewText: This film is a perfect storm, cast/acting, story, directing, all the elements come together perfectly. In the tradition of the works of Michael Mann, this film will go down as one of the greatest Neo-Noir films of all time. The stellar cast including: Ryan Gosling (whom really pulled of the strong silent anti-tough guy aesthetic) Albert Brooks (Bernie Rose), Ron Perlman (Nino "Izzy")  (both, very convincing as mid level, aging L.A. gangsters) Bryan Cranston (Shannon) Carey Mulligan (Irene) and my favorite, ginger-haired beauty, Christina Hendricks. (whom we know from Mad Men) Our unnamed protagonist, an underpaid mechanic (Ryan Gosling) moonlights as a  Hollywood stunt driver, and more significantly to the story, a wheel man for various criminals. When "friend", employer and schemer (Cranston)  decides that Gosling's talents as a driver could be quite lucrative in the world of Nascar. He approaches Gangster, Bernie Rose, to bankroll the venture. After seeing Gosling's skills on the track, Rose becomes exited with the prospect (the scene where Brooks extends his hand to Gosling, leads to one of the greatest lines in film, right up there with, "Go-ahead make my day" or "I love the smell of napalm in the morning" Gosling: "My hands are a little dirty." Brooks: "So are mine." I love that!) In the midst of all this, Gosling becomes non-romantically involved with a single mom (Carey Mulligan) As she and her son, await the release of her husband, "Standard" whom is serving hard time, for an unspecified crime. Though the relationship between Gosling and Mulligan seems have erotic potential. It appears to be more akin to, two lost souls making a much needed inter-personal connection. Gosling's feelings towards her son begin as mere sympathy yet, grow into outright fondness. Upon his release from prison, Mulligan's husband is awkwardly (and surprisingly) approving of the relationship. Though, seemingly remorseful for his crime(s). Standard gets caught up with the wrong people, IE: thugs, whom demand payment for: "protection in the joint", IE: a heist. Coincidentally? (and unbeknownst to Gosling) the thugs are employed by Bernie Rose's partner, Nino, AKA: Izzy. (Whom disapproves of Rose's Nascar venture, likely out of jealousy.) Gosling valiantly, but foolishly agrees to help (out of fear of harm to Irene or her son) as the wheel man. And from there...it all goes wrong. Was the whole thing a set-up? and if so, by whom? These are the great questions of great Neo-Noir's. The 80's-esque pop music doesn't fit the dark tone of the film, that's why it's perfect. As I stated, this film was heavily influenced by Michael Mann. Yet I can't call it a rip-off. The intertwining of lives, deceit, greed , betrayal, revenge and of course crime, as I said, all the elements come together. Even if Neo-Noir or Crime Drama is not your thing, you are still likely to enjoy this (very well done) film. Though I must warn you, the violence is graphic. As one might expect from a film of this nature.

reviewText: "Drive" looks, feels, and sounds like a present day homage to the groundbreaking 1980's film "To Live and Die in L.A.".To Live and Die in L.A. [Blu-ray].  Both movies deal with the sometimes fine line that people like police and criminals walk between wanting to wear white hats, wanting to wear black hats, and what their internal character ultimately drives them to be.Gosling portrays a car mechanic by day, part time thief by night who gets drawn into the mob world after he performs some racing stuntwork and catches the eye of bigger league criminals whose tentacles reach into the everyday world. A love interest from his apartment building pulls his character towards more noble directions, as he watches her struggle with first raising her child alone, and then back with a troubled husband after he is released from prison. As the husband's past life comes back to haunt him and endangers the family he now can't be a part of, Gosling decides to fight back against the corrupting elements in fairly dramatic fashion. Although he sometimes comes across like a Charles Bronson straight out of "Deathwish", taking out low level thugs and mob bosses alike, he ultimately knows he has much in common with those he is killing. This realization doesn't sit well with him, leading to a climax where he cares little if he lives or dies. Going out as "one of the good guys" might be for the best, ending things before his true nature has a chance to kick back in.All arthouse jokes aside, if you look at the scorpion on Gosling's jacketDrive (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)and recall the fable of the scorpion and the frog, you know the movie's theme:  when the scorpion stings the frog as they cross a river, drowning them both, and the frog asks "why did you do that?", all the scorpion can say is "I can't help it, it's in my nature".Criticism of Gosling's performance isn't entirely off base, some scenes are slow and the dialogue can be scant. But this can also perhaps be justified by the character and the film's director.  Lets face it, he plays a person who ISN'T right in the head. He's not going to, and shouldn't, act normal. Although not perfect, it works. Any detraction here is also more than made up for by the strong performance of Albert Brooks. Played for most of the movie as the "nice guy" criminal compared to his evil business partner (Ron Perlman), his true character comes to light in the end with a chilling scene (spoiler alert) where he is forced to kill a likable loser of a friend with an old trademark weapon he thought he had hung up a long time ago. It's one of several memorable scenes where Brooks steals the show. At one point Gosling won't shake hands with Brooks because grease makes his hands dirty.  Brooks insists on the handshake anyways. "So are mine".If you want to see something like a straight up action movie similar to "The Transporter", this isn't it. But if you want to go back in time to the early eighties, taking a little bit of "Miami Vice", a dash of "Scarface", and even a pinch of "Halloween" with some arthouse posing, then "Drive" will take you where you want to go.
summary: To Live and Drive in L.A. (bluray review)

reviewText: Wow. Reading the reviews on Drive is like listening to Republicans and Democrats debate health care - Lots of noise and everybody seems to miss the point.Here's the deal.Drive is an unapologetic riff of pretty much every loner crime revenge story ever made and total line descendant of Michael Mann's Thief from 1980, . So much so, that thanks to the bubbly soundtrack, it seems they might as well have filmed it in 1980 too. Drive is a small-time crime story told with great restraint on characterizations and great explosiveness when it comes to violence. As far as modern influences go, Drive is a sort of crazy hybrid of Paul Verhoeven's Spetters and Paul Thomas Anderson's Hard Eight (Sydney) throw in the last few Cronenberg movies while you're at it.While I don't quite understand the negativity so many haters seem to have for Drive, I understand why some people could be so frustrated by it. Drive is told with Nicolas Winding Refn's European eye for detail and tone. Drive is the definition of character study with a heavy emphasis on STUDY. There is very little quick cutting between camera setups and absolutely zero sitcom-esque axial cut dialog scenes. It is the antithesis of the way most American movies are made. We have been conditioned as a society to watch boxes of talking heads broken up with pointless jabber and largely bloodless violence.  On the other hand, I find it hard to call Drive a masterpiece simply because the director knows how to hold a shot instead of a cut every 6 seconds.Now how you interpret Drive's way to tell a story is largely a question of style and sensibility. Drive is not for every taste and probably not something you'll be in the mood to watch 24/7, but it is very well done when you have the time to invest in it. While it breaks no new ground - and if you think it does, you must have been born yesterday - Drive is a really immersive odyssey of moments and music. It's essentially the cruise through LA crime movie Michael Mann tried to make with the Hit-Man centered Collateral.Drive is better.

reviewText: People either love or hate this film, but I'm the strange one who feels both sides. On the positive side, it's beautifully filmed and paced. These aspects make parts of it like the Japanese "Shall We Dance", or a Wong Kai War's "In the Mood For Love", though the tension and dread have your stomach in knots already. The acting was strong and the music was wonderful, though I felt having the lyrics of "a real hero" blasted in my face did not work so well. On the not so positive side, this seemed like a typical violent revenge movie. Yes, I got that the Driver was closed emotionally and his neighbor and child brought out love feelings for him that he may not have understood, but for him kill everyone like a pro when things go wrong? The story seemed to indicate that the Driver was not a trained killer, but he sure knew how to dominate every time. In "First Blood", viewers had some idea of why Rambo took revenge and was alienated. However, in "Drive", we are supposed to believe that an introverted man will step up to help when he has feelings for a woman, and then become a sociopathic killer to "save the day". Not only that, but help the woman's obviously "in too deep" husband. Did anyone imagine the heist going well? While it was nice to have a somewhat ambiguous ending and long silent shots, the film when over-the-top in showing violence, letting us see extreme graphic detail. The upside of the violence is that it was very uncomfortable to watch, like real life, the downside is that it seemed like nothing to the characters. I'm sure the filmakers did all of the above on purpose to create a stylized "epic". The one thing that did not seem to make sense in the world the film created was the chase scene after the heist. Here we have the well-established amazing driver having no luck shaking the mobster car, though finally breaking away by what might have been luck or error by the mobster car. Watch "Drive" if your favorite films are "Scarface", "Reservoir Dogs", or similar. For the rest of us, it's a stylish nightmare.

reviewText: Very few films can capture the intensity that `Drive' is able to contain, and do so with such bridled passion for every frame.  What Nicolas Winding Refn does here is similar in scope to what David Fincher was able to achieve with last years `The Social Network'.  Every frame is beautifully composed to exact from us the precise emotion relevant to our understanding and appreciation of the film's structural progression.In other words, this is the directorial masterpiece of the year.But, `Drive' is far more than a mere moody masterwork.  A friend of mine mentioned that this is cinematic to the bone, and that is so true.  Every frame is a visual work of genius, so expressive in its ability to convey richness in tones with a mere shading of atmosphere.  The way that the film is perfectly edited (I mean, for a film so brisk in running time, it manages to fill it's frames with intense action AND detailed character development) suits the film's overall progression and remains instilled in the audience's mind long after the credits have finished rolling.  With muted moments (the dialog is far less important than the body language), `Drive' is a stunning cinematic achievement in a year composed and stunning cinematic achievements (seriously, this year is AMAZING).Ryan Gosling adds yet another knock out performance to his long list of intriguing and diverse characters.  Here he plays a driver (never named) who spends his days working in a garage for a man named Shannon who gets him in to do stunt work for movies and also, when needed, to drive getaway for crooks.  By chance, this driver meets a young mother in the same apartment building he is in.  Her name is Irene and her husband is currently serving time in prison.  They obviously have a connection but that connection is severed when her husband, Standard, is released from prison.  Standard owes some bad people some money but he is unable to pay it, and since the driver doesn't want to see something bad happen to Irene or her son, he offers to help Standard out.Big mistake.The second half of `Drive' shifts gears from brooding character study to intensity driven action flick, but those two worlds mesh marvelously thanks to Gosling's impenetrable stare and Winding Refn's superb handling of each scene's emotional dimensions.  The 80's inspired soundtrack coupled with the purposeful toying with time and speed (that elevator sequence is particularly magnificent) help establish `Drive' as an entity all its own.Yes, this is NOT what you think it'll be, but it is everything you could ask it to be.

reviewText: The Driver (or “The Kid” as he’s sometimes called) has no real name, at least nothing that’s ever spoken. He is what he does, and that is drive cars. When he’s not being paid to do so as a movie stunt man, he’s paid by criminals as a driver-for-hire. He feels little attachment to others and speaks even less. Still, beneath the silent exterior there’s a hidden depth where he keeps his moral convictions and code. This kind of hero is familiar, if a bit old school. The Driver is clearly modeled after characters like Steve McQueen’s Frank Bullitt, Clint Eastwood’s the Man with no Name, Toshiro Mifune’s Yojimbo, or even Alain Delon’s Jef Costello. In this case, where his true nature is revealed comes from his associations with his neighbor Irene and her son, Benicio.Even though the title is Drive, there isn’t actually all that much driving to be seen in this movie. There are a few chase sequences, and they’re well shot with no visible use of CGI, but the bulk of the movie follows the Driver as he interacts with Irene and her son, which allows him to display a hint of his humanity, which seems to be something that hasn’t surfaced in a long time. The first reveal of the character is while he’s working. The movie even begins with him firmly explaining the rules that go along with hiring him. It reminded me a little of The Transporter, but luckily the similarities end there. While on the job, we see the way in which he drives. He’s a true professional, and is not about long and over-the-top car chases. Instead, we see him triumph over the police through his knowledge of the streets and ability to blend into his surroundings (he even drives a Chevy Impala).The characters are crucial to the flow of the story, and it’s refreshing to see their importance placed over the need to meet expectations of the typical car chase movies. The cast is excellent, featuring Ryan Gosling as the nameless stone-faced protagonist. Although Danish director Nicholas Winding Refn adds a lot of style to the film and really tries to present Gosling as a tough character to match some of the examples I compared him to, he never quite reaches those heights. The character works, but Ryan Gosling doesn’t have the same screen presence as, for example, Steve McQueen does. Maybe he’s just too young, but he lacks that look of someone who’s had a lot of bad experiences and a tough past. As Irene, Carey Mulligan is adorable and fits the part of her role (though it’s a bit difficult to imagine how she ended up married to a criminal), and Bryan Cranston also gives an understated performance as Shannon, the man who hired the Driver and repairs/modifies his cars. The real scene stealers come from the bad guys however, who run a local pizza joint in L.A. They represent a Jewish sect of a larger mob family apparently, with Albert Brooks’s character being a former action movie producer turned organized crime boss. He’s in no way meant to be humorous (and trust me, he isn’t), and his partner is played by the always entertaining Ron Perlman, a mobster who resents the small time operation he runs with Brooks on the west coast. The two of them are vicious and ruthless killers who, through an uncanny string of bad luck and circumstances, find themselves at war with the Driver.The film is very stylized and though it seems to hearken back to action films of the ‘60s and ‘70s, it has an almost oddly ‘80s feel to it due to the synthesizer-heavy soundtrack (though this choice of music may be due to the European tastes of the director). There’s a lot of slow motion and Refn takes his time telling the story, focusing primarily on developing his characters. Interestingly, because of the reserved and backstoryless nature of the protagonist, a few of his “bonding” scenes with Irene are shown through montage, which keeps us at a constant distance with him. This makes the hyper-violent actions scenes all the more shocking, because we aren’t shown that he’s capable of that level of violence. Still, making the film about the Driver instead of his actual driving is a good choice and makes the story that much more interesting when the action does present itself. Compared to other films in this genre, Drive is an interesting change of pace and a stylish alternative to the sub-par norm. It’s packed with good performances and tells a compelling and layered story. And isn’t watching Albert Brooks stab someone worth the price of admission?

reviewText: `Drive' really surprised me. I was never really interested in seeing this, I'd read the articles and seen the posters and ended up dismissing it, I only watched it because there wasn't anything else and didn't have high expectations. But, as it turns out, the film really blew my first impressions away. Instead of being bored, I found myself drawn into the film and caring for its characters, the acting was spot-on and Refn's direction made this movie a real gem.Ryan Gosling is Driver, a solitary guy who works as a mechanic and stunt car driver by day and getaway driver-for-hire at night, that is until he meets his neighbour, Irene (Carey Mulligan), and her son. The more time he spends with them, he falls for Irene in a somewhat romantic fairy tale....until it all comes crashing down when Irene's ex-con husband (Oscar Isaac) returns, bringing with him trouble and compelling Driver to protect Irene and her son from gangsters.What really stops this movie from becoming a cookie-cutter action-drama film is the fact that director Nicolas Winding Refn concentrates on giving us well-rounded characters. It's the characters that drive `Drive', not the action or the story and Refn's stylistic way of shooting it - with slow-motion and lingering shots of characters and still camera work - makes sure that what's unspoken speaks the loudest as he leaves it up to you to interpret their feelings and thoughts. It's not what happens when they speak, but more what goes unspoken through looks and body language. I don't know what you call it - noir or artistic or whatever - it's an approach that's been used by many directors before, but it makes `Drive' absorbing to watch.Of course, it wouldn't work without the actors giving top-notch performances and nobody lets the movie down here. Gosling is magnetic as Driver, conveying layers of emotion without uttering a word in some scenes. Albert Brooks and Ron Perlman also give stellar performances that make them more than one-dimensional villains. The one surprise for me was Bryan Cranston, I don't watch `Breaking Bad', but he proves he can stretch his acting chops far beyond quirky sit-com comedy characters. Carey Mulligan, Oscar Isaac, the criminally underused Christina Hendricks, all did admirably and were very believable in their roles.There are scenes of action throughout the film as well and they can be shockingly brutal, especially when compared to the mostly quiet tone of the film, one particular character's demise from a shot gun through a window will stick with me for a while and the car chases are tight and well executed.But this isn't an action film first, if I had to call it something, I'd say it's more like an artsy, character-driven drama. Whether you'll enjoy it or not probably depends on whether you think long, quiet, reflective scenes with lingering shots of characters staring at each other are thought-provoking and beautiful, or a director being self-indulgent and pretentious. Personally, I loved it because it engaged me emotionally and the cinematography work was stunning, this is one that stayed with me long after the credits rolled.

reviewText: 'I'd been hearing about it for a while, and I had to admit I didn't get the buzz.  "It's a really great film!"  "This movie is really surprising people!"  "Ryan Gosling is terrific!"Ryan Gosling?  What?  The baby-faced guy from "The Notebook"?  The nut from "Lars and the Real Girl"?Yes--the same guy.  And boy, does he deliver."Drive" is a movie that will sit in your head for days after you see it.  This is a very strange film, not easily definable, and not at all what you think it's going to be.It's romantic.  It's very violent.  It has several twists in it that I found either shocking or disturbing, or both.  And it's a film that makes no bones about making it extremely difficult to pin characters down into easy stereotypes.Don't worry: I won't provide any spoilers.  I'll just say this: Gosling plays a near silent man named/described as, simply, Driver.  An absolute whiz behind the wheel, when he's not busy at his day job as a car mechanic or a Hollywood stunt driver he moonlights as a man who will drive questionable guys where they need to go, no questions asked.  Here's how he puts it..."There's a hundred-thousand streets in this city. You don't need to know the route. You give me a time and a place, I give you a five minute window. Anything happens in that five minutes and I'm yours. No matter what. Anything happens a minute either side of that and you're on your own."And that's almost all he says throughout the film.  But he really doesn't need to...he speaks pages with those great eyes, whether he's admiring Irene, watching over her young son Benicio, or staring the hell out of some rotten guy who is trying to hurt them.In the manner of the great Steve McQueen, Gosling is able to express an awful lot with those baby blues, and his near silence really works to establish him as a man who speaks rarely but is by no means inexpressive.  It's hard not to latch on to his iconic smile when he sees Irene, and to understand his feeling of dismay when he finds out she has an ex-con husband who's coming home from prison in a couple of days.And that's when the trouble begins.  It's easy to see that Driver does best when he lives on his own terms, but now he feels he needs to watch out for Irene's loser of a husband and that's when things begin to get ugly.  I mean, real ugly.  And Driver finds himself embroiled in a war he didn't want, but to his credit he won't back away, either.  It's all in those eyes: you just know he won't let Irene or Benicio down.There's quite a pedigree in this film, too: Carey Mulligan is Irene, Albert Brooks is a crime boss, as is his hair trigger partner Ron Perlman, and Bryan Cranston is Gosling's boss at the garage,  There are several other young actors of note here as well, but much credit has to go to the movie's director, Nicolas Winding Refn, a Danish director who is no stranger to violent movies about the dark underbelly of life, most recently directing 2009's "Bronson," starring Tom Hardy (soon to become Bane, Batman's formidable nemesis in "The Dark Knight Rises.")  Refn does a fine job letting the film speak for itself, letting its actors walk a fine line between the notions of good and evil, making it very hard to pick absolutes within this film.In fact, when this movie is over it is very hard to clearly define anyone within this movie, and that includes Driver.  "Drive" is willing to allow itself to intermingle traditional concepts of right and wrong, and very few people can be easily categorized here.  It makes for interesting watching, and will probably make the film resonate for you for quite a while.If you hadn't guessed, I'm most impressed with Gosling, whom I'd thought was a simple hot chickflick guy who filled in the blanks when a romantic movie needed a hot dude.  But I realize now that he'd done the same thing in "The Notebook," too.  He says a lot without saying a lot.  He definitely has acting chops.I'm looking forward to Gosling's next role, "Only God Forgives," a Bangkok thriller pairing him with Refn once again.  Also along for the ride is Kristen Scott Thomas.  Gosling was reported as describing the script of "Only God Forgives" as "the strangest thing I've ever read and it's only going to get stranger."And this from a man who made "Drive."  I can't wait.
summary: Drive: Much more than I thought it would be

reviewText: Ryan Gosling is about to have a really big year and movies like DRIVE are a big reason. DRIVE is a stylistic artistic noire thriller that at times seems to be a throwback to movies of the 80s like "To Live and Die in L.A." or "No Man's Land" and at times is as grisly and violent as a Quentin Tarantino film. Apart from that, DRIVE is in a category all its own.The director of DRIVE, Nicolas Winding Refn, is sort of new on the scene and his style in this movie is to be respected and remembered. Too often these days movies and their directors think they have to blow everything up and dazzle you with constant barrages of events, but Refn proved that not to be true. Each and every scene in this film tells a little story and not a single one of those scenes should or can be missed. So, take care of your refreshment and bathroom duties before hand.Ryan Gosling plays a man simply known as Driver. Driver is a soft spoken enigma of a man, who races cars, drives stunt cars for the movies, hires himself out for getaway jobs, works as a mechanic and eventually through a course of events, ends up in the middle of a heist that changes his life forever. Driver is a man of few words, but has a coolness that had me thinking of Steve McQueen in Bullitt or a suave James Dean.The most notable thing about DRIVE is its style and its quiet ability to make you the audience feel like you are in the same room with the characters, watching the thing take place in real time. It isn't just a violent action film, it's a story of people and how people affect each other. The scenes where driver (Gosling) is barreling down the highway at break neck speeds are meaningless without the quiet scenes he spends with the neighbor and her child watching cartoons and living a normal life. Those quiet scenes invest you in the lives of the people on screen.I haven't seen a movie in years that had me so invested in the characters. The movie sucks you in. I only wish the entire movie was as glorious, rich and unique as the build up. Unfortunately, the surprises and uniqeness of the film don't carry over into the ending.
summary: Throw back to the 80's with a splash of PULP FICTION

reviewText: I shouldn't have waited so long to see Drive. I *didn't* see it until now for the same reasons probably many people *did* go see it, and were then disappointed: in my area, it was marketed like a car chase action movie. I have to be in the right mood for those, and I just wasn't at the time it was in theaters. But I should have gone to see it on the big screen when it was out (and I should have remembered that Gosling was compulsively watchable in Half Nelson). Instead I finally saw it via Netflix on my 47" TV. There is a local movie revival house that sometimes screens cult movies at midnight or matinees, and I'm hoping that they screen Drive one of these days, so I can finally see it on the big screen. I feel it should be seen on a big screen, although it fares well on a big screen TV in a small living room!Drive is no car chase movie. And although there is a lot of driving, much of it is meditative and quiet, the protagonist (Ryan Gosling) alone in his car, safely ensconced away from the rest of the world. Despite the dangers inherent in the stunt (and getaway car) driving he does, he is such a tightly wound and controlled character that you sense there is little danger in what he does for a living, and that he is in total control of the car. The problem is that life lever lets anyone stay in total control for long, and life is far more dangerous in its unpredictability than the controlled and choreographed chaos of a movie set.Others have described the plot in detail, so I won't go into it here, except to say that while it seems to be fairly simple and straightforward, the old adage applies. Simple does not necessarily mean easy as many a 40s noir pic has told  us before. The protagonist's efforts to positively influence the outcome of the situations unfortunately do not bear the fruit you sense he hopes for.This is a movie that tells its story with a stylized visual economy and surprisingly little dialogue. It tells the story without telegraphing major plot points first, yay; I'm so tired of movies having to foreshadow everything so heavily because they assume the audience is stupid. As a result, I was genuinely surprised by the plot twists, which doesn't often happen to me anymore. Yet despite the fact that Drive's clear, often stark visuals tell the story in a fairly straightforward, if noir and moody, style, it bears repeat watching -- I'm already on my third viewing.Gosling gives a finely nuanced performance, but I felt the rest of the ensemble were all very well cast, especially Brian Cranston, Albert Brooks, and Ron Perlman. Carey Mulligan is possibly the weakest link, though not really, since her character seems deliberately somewhat emotionally ambiguous and fuzzy-edged. I wondered while watching how Michelle Williams might have played it, but that's nothing against Mulligan; she pulls it off with a similarly nuanced performance to Gosling's, but it is Gosling and Cranston who really stand out. Christina Hendricks, who has only a bit part, also holds her own in her scenes, although her character is the least developed and the most cliche. Brooks plays against type the most, but Perlman is effective in his coarse, greedy, mob-connected character.Mulligan and Gosling build a believable sexual tension and chemistry until you are practically aching for them to come together in a way you sense they must be aching for each other. As the plot unfolds, you realize that both hold themselves back from each other and are somewhat reserved, either by their nature (Gosling's character) or by their circumstances (Mulligan's), or both.When Gosling's character seizes the moment and they finally come together, he passionately unfurls all that pent up tension and Mulligan's character authentically responds. The immediate aftermath of that sweetness and passion makes it even more poignant, when it quickly becomes apparent that it was motivated as much or more by a fierce protectiveness as it was by passion. His protectiveness is necessarily brutal in eliminating a truly evil threat, in the way that men fiercely protect that which they most care about. But his brutality clearly unnerves and frightens her, in the way that women always become frightened of men when they show their true capacity for violence.This story is told with a beautiful visual economy. There are cliche-ish helicopter-shot overhead views of the glittering downtown LA skyscrapers sprinkled here and there throughout the movie. Yet you sense that those are included to contrast with the low level interior shots in the apartments, grocery store, auto shop, and especially inside the cars, which feel even more intimate by comparison. The cinematography and direction portray this interior/exterior dichotomy. The vast majority of the truly bloody violence occurs in close quarters between people. The car chases, crashes, and the use of cars as weapon are the only non-bloody violence, and they naturally occur outside. It's as if, in the protagonist's world, the threat posed by people and their physical proximity is much more dangerous than the implied threats of violence inherent in cars driven for stunts or robbery getaways.The dialogue is also very economical. One of the most interesting aspects of the film is that so much is told visually, you almost don't need dialogue at all in the first 40-45 minutes of the movie. Paradoxically, the chemistry between Gosling and Mulligan is enhanced by them so rarely speaking. Her shining eyes, the upturned corner of his lip, the way they hold each other's gazes -- it really builds the tension. The same goes for the relationship that builds between her son Benicio and the Driver. A lot of it is built in smiles, stares, and shared gazes, before he ever picks the kid up to carry him inside to bed.I would be remiss if I didn't mention the soundtrack. There is a reason it was hot on Itunes last year. Though the moods conjured are very different, the way the soundtrack was used in Drive reminded me a lot of the way the soundtrack was used in The Virgin Suicides (which was scored by Air, not Cliff Martinez, who scored Drive). I was surprised, and then not, when I found out that Cliff Martinez had also done the soundtrack to Soderberg's remade Solaris with Clooney, which was also very haunting and moody. The synthy electronica of Drive's soundtrack harkens back to the 80s for me, but it still feels very modern in its throwback/retro way. It also reminded me a bit of the soundtrack to Risky Business, by Tangerine Dream. Turns out (I read later) that that was intentional on the part of the director.If you liked those soundtracks and the way they suited and underscored the mood and characters of those movies, you'll probably like Drive's soundtrack. By the same token, if you like the synthpop sounds of the likes of Kraftwerk, early Depeche Mode (when Vince Clarke was still with them, before he started Yaz with Alison Moyet), Yaz, and Gary Numan, you'll like Drive's soundtrack. I always hated the way that so many 80s and 90s movies turned into stitched together music videos, with dialogue-less scenes where the protagonist trains for his/her wrestling meet/dance-off to the sounds of some 80s pop. In those particular movies (Virgin Suicides, Risky Business, and Drive), though the soundtrack is almost a character in the film, it is not off-putting to me the same way those stupid movie montages are... probably because none of those movies have those stupid protagonist-training-for-wrestling-meet/dance-competition scenes.I have not seen other movies by this director, but I plan to. And next time Gosling is in a film, I'll go see it, no matter how it's marketed (or mis-marketed), because so far everything I've seen him in has been really good, or he's been really good in it, or both. While he theoretically has that eye candy appeal, he really doesn't show any skin in this movie. (Although he is rather poured into his tight jeans, white Ts, and denim jacket. But then, Christina Hendricks is similarly poured into her clothes). In fact, none of the main characters shows any skin in this movie, and the movie does not suffer for that. Later, a brief scene in a strip club show tons of T&A.; But that scene is so matter of fact, and the strippers are such copies of each other, they're more like Stepford Strippers. That this is the only scene with nudity of any kind makes me wonder if the director meant to thumb his nose at the ubiquity of nudity in Hollywood. In fact, that lack of skin for the two main characters -- the Driver and Irene -- might be what makes their relationship that much more compelling, in this era of "show everything."A note about the violence: some people would undoubtedly describe this as a terribly violent film. I disagree; I've seen gorefests that had 20 times the amount of violence and gore that this film has.What sets Drive's violence apart is the fact that it is not action porn; it is violent punctuation of the story's plot points. It reminded me of the violence in Eastern Promises: brief but startling, brutal, bloody and realistic. This is not the kind of violence you cheer on like an action hero offing his numerous opponents in cartoonish, splattery ways. This is much more like real life violence: infrequent, short-lived, brutal, bloody, and liable to make you upset or at least uncomfortable. Be prepared for that.
summary: NOT an action/car chase movie: deeper, cooler, more ethereal and haunting (NO SPOILERS)

reviewText: I bought this movie earlier this year.  However, it is only recently that I have been driven to take the time to write a review of it.  I loaned the DVD to my best friend and we discussed it afterwards.  That discussion is what drove me to write this review.This is one of those "atmosphere" movies, in my view.  The atmosphere in the scenes sort of took the attention away from the characters and the plot.  Especially that very last scene, after the kid's confrontation with the mobster.  And that need to emphasize the atmosphere also made the movie slow-moving.The main character is a mysterious young man who makes his living doing stunt work for cheap movies.  On the side, he moonlights as a criminal who transports people in exchange for cash.  Sort of like the Frank Martin character in the Transporter franchise.  But make no mistake.  This is a much darker, much more violent movie than the Transporter trilogy.The driver is a loner, living alone, speaking only to those he must.  You get the impression that he has experienced a lot of trauma.  There is a sadness about him, but also confidence.  He's one of those people that carries a lot of pain with him.  Trouble starts when he opens the emotional door and makes friends with his neighbor, a young woman living alone with her young son.  As he spends time with them, he becomes attach to them.  Later, the woman's husband completes his prison sentence and comes back to live with them.  The driver ends up becoming friends with Gabriel, the husband.  Unfortunately for them, Gabriel's old associates are not finished with him.  To help the family, the driver agrees to help Gabriel pull off a robbery.  And talk about a robbery gone bad!The movie stars Ryan Gosling, Carrie Mulligan, Albert Brooks, and Ron Pearlman.  This is one movie where the acting is beyond reproach.  Gosling reaffirms his position as one of Hollywood's rising stars.  And Albert Brooks, in an atypical role for him, plays his nemesis.  The movie would rate as over-the-top in violence.  Action is pretty good.  The driving scenes are done very well.  This is not Ryan Gosling's best work, but it is pretty good.  Be forewarned that this is not anything like the Transporter movies.  This one is very violent.  Much too violent than it needs to be, in my opinion.  It does try too hard to make the driver larger than life.  In a way, this makes him somewhat unrealistic or implausible in a non-human way.  He reminds me of Lt. Martin Castillo in the Miami Vice television series.

reviewText: From the previews of this film I thought I was going to be seeing another TRANSPORTER type film, only instead of Statham, it was now starring Ryan Gosling! To some, it may sound stupid, or even boring but which, I thought would be "brilliant!" And from the first five minutes of the film, I can see how anyone might gather that connection. Well, if you too had that impression, you're wrong about one thing: This is NOT a TRANSPORTER film! From it's jarring 70's style poppy-techno-roller-disco vibe soundtrack to its eerie non-descript era and throwback locales this film quickly turns on a...well, pardon the pun, drive. Gosling takes on a departure role of action hero. Oh, it's not as bad as it sounds! He still plays it with that signature slow-to-the-draw subtle demeanor, but don't let that fool you. There's an elevator scene, which rivals Ed Norton's "head cruncher" in American History X, and during which time I had a notion to stand up and attempt to literally grab and shake Gosling by the shoulder (through the screen) and shout, "Ok, he's dead! He's dead!"Some surprisingly familiar and longtime seen faces crop up in this film, Ron Perlman ("Nino"), a 59 year old small town mobster who's tired of running the numbers game and just wants to retire in style; Albert Brooks in a stunning performance as a kind of Jeykle and Hyde character, who is both Nino's business partner and who also dabbles as a Race Car Owner; Bryan Cranston (Breaking Bad) as Gosling's go between/boss at an auto shop, and the very lovely and amazing Ms. Carey Mulligan (Never Let Me Go) as Gosling's love interest and next door neighbor . It may sound convient but soon gets messy when her ex-con husband arrives home from prison and starts making everyone work for their money.DRIVE is a surprising departure from the nauseating commonplace action films of Hollywood, it has guts and it sticks to your ribs like a good plate of steak and potatoes! I promise, not only will you NOT be disappointed, but also thoroughly surprised.

reviewText: This is not an action movie.  Repeat: this is not an action movie.Rather, it's a character study that just happens to contain some visceral action sequences.I want to make that clear right up-front, because I get the feeling that too many of the folks giving this movie one-star reviews walked into the theater with much the same kind of wrong expectations that did the individual who sued this movie's producers upon realizing the flick wasn't a "Fast and the Furious" clone.So guess what?  This movie *isn't* a "Fast and Furious" clone - and thank goodness for that.  Yes, "Drive" has action, and when it comes it can be viscerally graphic (again, unlike the "Furious" films, where thousands of cars and bodies are crushed but nary a drop of blood is often spilled).And yet much of the film unfolds in quiet, concentrated bursts of silent lyricism that highlight the interplay between characters.  It's that intense quiet, rather than the intense violence, that defines the film's central character.In sum: Director Nicolas Winding Refn combines polished camera work, rock solid editing, and a solid score with stellar performances by the principles (a note: you may never look at Albert Brooks in quite the same way again) to create one of my favorite films of 2011.(And hey, nothing too much against the "Furious" flicks - I kinda enjoyed that last one; it was genuinely fun, in its own vacuous way.)
summary: A Fantastic Character Study with Some Violent Passages

reviewText: Nicholas Winding Refn is a name I had never even heard of until 2009. That's when the action/biography film Bronson was released and I was introduced to both Refn and Tom Hardy. If you know me or have been reading my reviews for a decent amount of time, you've been hearing me rave about Bronson for awhile now. It's a fantastic film that made me a fan of both Refn and Hardy for life. As I'm still working through both of their filmographies (I'm still dying to get to Refn's Pusher trilogy), all of that was put on the back burner for what's happening now in the present. Refn's new film Drive has been unleashed upon the world and sweet monkey-slapping Jesus is it glorious.Driver (Ryan Gosling) has the uncanny ability of making something as simple as driving look like an art form. The things this guy does with a car are unbelievable. He spends the majority of his time working at a garage under the tutelage of Shannon (Bryan Cranston), but Shannon is also his partner. Driver lends his services to robberies to make some extra cash, which is where Shannon comes in. Then there's what Driver does part-time (it's more fun if you find out what that is for yourself). Driver seems to have things under control until he meets Irene (Carey Mulligan); a married woman with a kid whose husband is in prison. Driver begins to spend a lot of time with her and basically falls for her right as her husband is released from prison. That's when things get messy quick and Driver winds up in over his head.Drive was able to get Refn the best director award at Cannes and it's easy to see why. The story is an incredible balance of character development, building tension, and exquisite acts of brutality. The way Refn portrays all of that is pretty astounding. There's this winding perspective that's used several times in the film where we see someone walking down a long hallway or the aisle of a grocery store. It's a continuous shot as we always have our eyes on whoever is making this journey. It's simple, but memorable. The imagery in Drive is also incredible. The violence hits you like a ton of bricks and pretty much comes out of nowhere. There's a scene near the end of the film where Driver is sitting in his car with his shoes splattered with blood. It makes you contemplate whether the character is dead or not; the rich colors, the blazing sun behind him, and the lack of movement. The way Drive constantly parallels The Scorpion and the Frog is just icing on the cake. Everything about the film is just so absorbing.Ryan Gosling is really fantastic in this. He's a man of few words, but is more than happy to illustrate that actions speak louder than anything he has to say. But it's not like he doesn't have dialogue. He's just quiet, but in the way that makes you unsure of what he's actually capable of. Driver is unpredictable and Gosling portrays that really well. Menacing at times and downright scary at others, Driver has the best intentions in Drive even if the way he shows it is a bit unorthodox. It was also great to see Bryan Cranston have a supporting role. As a huge "Breaking Bad" fan, it was really entertaining to see Cranston take that intensity that he's known for on the show and bring it into another medium. Ron Perlman treads familiar ground in his performance, but still manages to steal quite a few scenes. Meanwhile, Albert Brooks is just as mesmerizing. He's a businessman first and just wants to do what's right for business, but isn't afraid to get his hands dirty. Carey Mulligan is the only one I'm still kind of up in arms about. I swear she just cries in every movie she's in yet she always manages to be a part of really spectacular films, so that has to say something.The car chases are enthralling. I know nothing about cars and generally don't really care too much about them. Popular car movies only appeal to me so much because I'm just not that into cars; plain and simple. Drive was at least able to trigger that interest. You see kids; extreme acts of violence are good for something after all. The opening car chase leaves you craving for more as it's both strategic and captivating. The one later on is a bit more rewarding as metal scrapes against metal and wheels go flying through the air. The violence in this is pretty heavy; blood paints walls on several occasions, there's one of the most graphic head shots ever, and the elevator scene will probably make you curse out loud. It's pretty amazing if you're into that sort of thing, but could be a turn off if you're not.Drive is essentially everything Faster should have been; violent when it needed to be, calm yet intriguing in its slower moments, a fantastic cast all around, and an intriguing story. Its 80s inspired music along with the typeface used in the opening and ending credits makes Drive feel like Grand Theft Auto: Vice City if it was turned into a movie. Drive is an unusual experience that toys with your emotions. It's borderline heartwarming in its first half while sending your adrenaline through the roof during the car chases. Its violent second half leaves you practically gob smacked. Drive is intense, brutal, and explosive. Nicholas Winding Refn and Ryan Gosling have delivered a frontrunner for the best film of the year.

reviewText: We know him as Driver.  He doesn't carry a gun; he drives.  That's his job, and he's good at it.  Why?  Because it's a job, plain and simple.  But then he makes the ultimate mistake: he makes it personal.  And now people have to pay.There's a beautifully misleading simplicity about DRIVE.  It isn't what you think.  Behind Ryan Gosling's emotionless face is a deep well of emotions: anger, disgust, amusement, empathy.  Gosling is perfect in the part, conveying equal parts machismo, rage, and compassion.  He doesn't say much, but he doesn't need to: Driver is a man of action, not words.  As his quasi-romantic interest, Carey Mulligan again dazzles.  With a lesser cast and crew, her role would be shallow, merely there to serve the plot; she makes it three-dimensional, her own.  The same goes for the various supporting players: Bryan Cranston, Oscar Isaac, Christina Hendricks, James Biberi, and Ron Perlman.  Kudos especially to Albert Brooks, who makes arguably the most plausible charming-to-sadistic transition in recent cinema.  Props must also be given to the ever-steady direction of Nicolas Winding Refn, and the above-par script by Hossein Amini (who penned the unfairly overlooked KILLSHOT).DRIVE isn't a film for everyone.  It's a slow-burning noir in the old fashioned style: an anti-hero who's as much villain as anything; a dame in distress who's really tough-as-nails (but still beautiful and vulnerable); a cast of characters who are mostly unlikable.  It'll certainly be a disappointment to anyone whose short attention span has been captivated by the various FAST AND FURIOUS films.  (You hear about the person who sued because they thought it was an action film?  Wonder if it's the same person who was surprised at how hot their McDonald's coffee was.)  But for those with patience, and appreciation for subtlety and nostalgia, DRIVE is the film you've been waiting for.

reviewText: I was watching the beginning of "Drive" on DVD and I was bored. "Drive" is very slow moving. I wondered what I was missing; the film had gotten rave reviews. I paused the DVD and read a few internet comments. One reviewer wrote, "Skip the first fifty minutes. It's boring. Fast forward to the end with all the interesting killings.""Drive" is a nihilistic, sadistic, nasty little film. There are graphic scenes of one man stomping another man to death. The victim's skull is depicted as having the fragility of an eggshell; his brains have the squishy consistency of chocolate pudding. A man places a nail into the forehead of an intended victim and threatens to hammer the nail. A man makes to shake another man's hand and pulls the man forward and slashes his arm open. There are also more conventional stabbings and shootings. I'm used to images of gore; my facebook friends tend to post the latest stoning, decapitation, or bombing videos. What sickened me about "Drive" was realizing that Hollywood executives cooked up all this nihilistic sadism as a moneymaking form of entertainment.Ryan Gosling plays The Man with No Name. He drives getaway cars for violent criminals. He develops a crush on Irene (Carey Mulligan) his neighbor. Her husband Standard (Oscar Isaac) has just gotten out of prison. Gosling offers to drive Standard in a heist. There are some Jewish gangsters, Ron Perlman and Albert Brooks.None of this is particularly believable or involving. I never forgot that most characters are actors. Oh, there's Albert Brooks, who usually plays a narcissistic whiner, who is now playing an atypical bad guy role. Oh, there's Ron Perlman, who was in Beauty and the Beast. Oh, there's Carey Mulligan, who just played Daisy in "The Great Gatsby." Oh, there's Bryan Cranston, from "Breaking Bad."It's impossible to believe that Mulligan and Isaac are married, or that Mulligan belongs in this movie at all. She looks like a dewy buttercup; Isaac looks like he could play Satan with no makeup. Mulligan totally lacks that Gloria Grahame feel of a true film noir heroine - beautiful, shopworn, tragic.The film moves very slowly. There is virtually no dialogue between Gosling and Carey Mulligan. The viewer has no idea why this woman breaks into Gosling's heart. You have no idea who Gosling is. He comes across as being too stupid or too smart; too amoral or too ethical; he's just not believable. None of the characters are likeable. This film could have had any number of endings, with everybody dead or everybody alive or the lovers united or the lovers apart, the money in the bank or the money in the backseat of the car. I just did not care. The film seems to exist only to satisfy that sad, creepy demographic of fans who pay to see "interesting killings.""Drive" gets more than one star for Gosling's performance. He is a brilliant actor who can do anything. I just wish he would not waste his gifts on drek like this.
summary: Slow Moving, Anonymous, Nihilistic Sadism; Gosling is Brilliant, As Ever

Drive, along with his previous films like Bronson and the Pusher trilogy, is not necessarily a reinvention of modern cinema, but more or less a reinterpretation of the days of Cinema past. Refn is startlingly good, so good I get goosebumps just from watching his scenes take time and build up. Finally the likes of Scorsese and Cronenberg can take it easy, and Tarantino and the Coens can step aside to make way for the next great talent in film direction: Nicolas Winding Refn.Drive takes its lead from, quite possibly, the coolest film ever made. Jean-Pierre Melville's 1967 magnum opus Le Samourai.Refn's creation, the character of the Driver, is cut from the same cloth as Le Samourai's Jef Costello.  The characters share several likenesses, the least important of which being a mysterious and sordid past. The most important likeness being the almost ritualistic way both characters carry out the tasks assigned to them, the lonely lives in which they traverse through a disconnected and oblivious habitat, the trust that doesn't come easy but when it does it is given to a pretty girl who seals both of their fates, and most interestingly, the eyes. Ryan Gosling must have studied Alain Delon's performance as they both seem to communicate most of the plot-points with their eyes and only their eyes. The Driver's real name could easily have been Jef Costello as far as I'm concerned. This is also telling of how many different ways the same film can be so influential to extremely different ends. This polarity is best explored by the movies Drive and John Woo's 1989 The Killer. Both films are flamboyantly open about the debt each owes to the influence of Le Samourai. Where Drive is almost an arthouse action film, the Killer is the exact opposite of that. But influence on either film is unmistakable, Le Samourai wrote the book, and Refn has memorized each and every passage. Yes, it doesn't just stop with Gosling's performance, Drive owes a great deal to Le Samourai in almost every single department. The pacing Refn embraces is classic Melville, the way he tells the story is almost formulaic of a Melville crime picture. Drive, in essence, is an American action film with 60s French sensibilities. People may seem to give Drive too much credit in the originality department, where much of the credit is Melville-deserved. But I don't hold anything against Drive for being almost a reinterpretation Le Samourai. I see Drive for what it was always meant to be, the warmest and most sincere thank you letter to classic Cinema ever filmed. Refn does no hiding when it comes to the Melville influence, its there staring you right in the face. Bravo, Drive, Bravo! Melville would be proud.What is most unique about Drive is the fact that the film is just as much a salute to the French New Wave of the sixties as it is a reimagining of the mainstream American cinema of the eighties. Surprisingly enough, in a film that boasts a very large and formidable Arthouse following, 1986's Cobra, 1985's To Live And Die In L.A., and several other nods to 80s cinema is almost interchangeable with the 60s influence. Where the 60s influence may be much more subtle and much more consistent throughout, the 80s influence is mostly on the surface. The 80s influence in Drive is of the strictly superficial variety, which is both faithful and respectful of the 80s films and techniques certain areas of the film are modeled after. Neon pink title card, synthesizer soundtrack, mood changes, the poster art, and the occasional trademark 80s lighting. Although a caricature like Marion 'Cobra' Cobretti can in fact be found on the surface of the character of the Driver, that is only the surface, it is not the actual substance of the character. The substance of the character is Le Samourai's Jef Costello. Its almost as if the movie's true colors are of the Melville variety, but it masquerades itself as something much more accessible. Drive pretends to be an 80s American action film. But Drive is so much than that, as any semi-educated cinefile will tell you, Drive is film that wears several different masks. Its true identity is that of Melville. And I can't think of a better frame of mind than that.Cast-wise, yes, Albert Brooks steals the show. The character Brooks plays is also one of the only non-french influences on the film. Bernie Ross is wholly American, and that is why he is such a vicious character. Bernie Ross is an 80s action villain, and he is pitted against a 60s character study. The clash is almost inevitable, but the mutual respect is the most rewarding aspect of their relationship. Same can be said about fans of the Arthouse and of the Mainstream. There is a mutual respect there, although all too often these sects of film fans and filmmakers will clash, they are nothing without the other. That said, in theory the rift between Bernie Ross and the Driver can be symbolic of several different things: Mainstream vs Arthouse, Excess vs Conservation, Action vs Meditation, European sensibilities vs American know-how, but most daringly it represents the Death Of Modern Cinema. All the greats are killing each other. Film cannot survive in a climate of servitude to the past. Mainstream wounds the Arthouse, the Arthouse fights back. Both the Mainstream and the Arthouse refuses to let go of their history, therefore they are doomed to tell the same stories over and over again, and cut the other's throat when necessary. The current state of filmmaking is in a very sad state of affairs as of late, Drive is a film that pits over-used caricatures, genres, and eras, popular of modern visual storytelling, against each other, until once everything is done, destroyed, and wounded. All you are the left with are the end credits, and the promise of a stripped down and re-imagined future in filmmaking.Overall, Drive is a perfect film. If you haven't seen it, I recommend that you do so immediately. If you have seen it, I don't care if you liked it or not, WATCH IT AGAIN. This film is trying to communicate the world to you, open up and listen.

Each person will interpret a book, movie, game, or album in a different fashion, unique to their experience. On to the review:Drive has some moments that are executed magnificently, particularly the opening getaway sequence, which is full of quiet, subdued tension. As "Driver" (seriously, that's what he's called... but we'll get to the hackneyed writing shortly) attempted to safely navigate the streets of Los Angeles, with his two paying clients in the backseat, I felt as if I were riding along in the car, with my fingers tightly wrapped around the dashboard. The two thieves sit huddled in the backseat, silent, sweating, their eyes filled with fear, as the car darts from shadow to shadow, evading the pursuing police cruisers and the spotlight of a hovering helicopter. The fact that I was able to sympathize so strongly with the anxiety of these criminals, who I knew nothing about so early in the movie, is testimony to an impressive piece of film making.As the story unfolds, we find that Driver (REALLY, that's his name) is a part time wheel man, while also working as a mechanic and a stunt man in the city. He seems to have no particular direction for his life, but his new romantic interest leads him into a downward spiral of crime, violence, and self destruction.Unfortunately, this movie is held back by juvenile writing. In one scene, Driver actually utters the following line, which is typical of his dialogue (and which made me burst out with laughter): "How about this... You shut your mouth, or I'll kick your f**** teeth in, and shut it for you!" At this point, I'm wondering: Who wrote this, a 15 year old boy? I have worked extensively with high school students, and I assure you... this is exactly how teenage boys write dialogue, when they're trying to summon the image of super tough, cool characters who take no guff. What makes this over-the-top lines even harder to swallow is how Driver is generally a silent, moody, nobody-understands-me type of character (again... high school male, anybody?). Furthermore, the scenes where violence comes into play is WAY over the top, to the point where it's just ludicrous, and employed for purposes of shock value, not moving the story forward. Ultimately, this hackneyed approach left Drive a movie that was difficult for me to enjoy.

reviewText: Every moment of Nicholas Winding Refn's 'DRIVE' demonstrates a superb collaboration between director and principal artists, especially with the main character, the Driver, stunningly portrayed by the excellent actor Ryan Gosling. Here is a man who transforms himself from a mysterious character who operates with a kind of stillness and a very simple code,one who doesn't give himself away very often or very willingly,a loner and a drifter who doesn't care if he has any friends,the quintessential rugged American who transitions from this passive state to an incredibly violent and offensive stance.As comfortable driving stunt cars on a movie set by day as he is at night when he's a getaway driver for petty criminals, Gosling's character becomes engulfed in a world infused with tension as he goes up against vicious mobsters [Albert Brooks, who goes completely against type, and Ron Perlman, who has played 'heavies' before] seeking retribution when a heist goes awry.The Driver's love story with his attractive neighbor [Cary Mulligan-"An Education"] pares down to its bare essentials, the subtext revealed more by what the characters DON'T say, but by the way they look at each other. The film has a visceral, muscular quality that Refn applies even to the car chase sequences, which are not the typical high-speed variety one might expect, but instead demonstrate how the Driver uses his intelligence and expertise to achieve his objectives with nonetheless eye-popping results!'DRIVE' is an expertly-crafted tale of compelling characters acting as an ensemble with a consistent tone. The intense and studied pauses are as dramatic as the scenes rife with unmitigated force and violence, and the viewer eagerly follows the Driver, who sports a jacket emblazoned with a scorpion image, as he transforms from a man without any specific life goals, living and breathing by the moment with no game plan, to one who exacts terrifying revenge on the threatening mobsters. Do not miss this extraordinary work of art!

reviewText: DRIVE is a fascinating character study, one that uses a minimum of words to define a complex character in a manner than seems terrifyingly quiet and mesmerizing. Based on a book written by James Sallis the screenplay is the  minimalist yet secure writing of Iranian writer Hossein Amini (Wings of the Dove, The Four Feathers, Jude, Shanghai, Kill Shot, etc). Nicolas Winding Refn is the sensitive director who takes advantage of the pauses in the storyline, allowing cinematographer Newton Thomas Sigel to bring this mysterious story to life.An unnamed young man referred to as Driver (Ryan Gosling) is a loner, holding down several jobs as a Hollywood stunt driver, a garage mechanic, and a getaway driver who participates in robberies as a silent, by his own rules driver. He works for garage owner, the crippled Shannon (Bryan Cranston) who in turn works for criminals Bernie Rose (Albert Brooks) and Nino (Ron Perlman). Driver meets his apartment house neighbor Irene (Carey Mulligan) and her son Benicio (Kaden Leos) and while there seems to be a chemistry quietly building between them, Driver is told that Irene's husband Standard (Oscar Isaac) has been in prison and will be coming home soon.  Driver, Irene and Benicio bond and when Standard is finally released from prison Driver learns that Standard owes a huge protection debt and to befriend the only people about whom Driver cares, he agrees to help in a getaway car that turns very wrong. From this point the normally gentle and quiet driver transforms into a brutal man and the rest of the film is full of terror.Ryan Gosling is splendid in his role as the driver, saying more with his eyes and his body language and his silences than many actors say with a full script.  Carey Mulligan is likewise strong and the supporting roles by Albert Brooks, Oscar Isaac, Bryan Cranston, Ron Perlman, Christina Hendricks, James Biberi and even Russ Tamblyn (!) are superlative cameos.  This is a tough film, full of graphic violence, but it is such a unique story and is so well acted and directed that it is one of the year's most surprising quality movies. Grady Harp, February 12

reviewText: Ugh, this movie...It's weird to try and write a critical review of Drive because soooo many people respond soooo strongly to it.  And, despite what little enjoyment I got out of it, I'm going to have to recommend it.  Because my opinion is so deep in the minority.  Christ, this thing's got a Rotten Tomatoes rating nearly as high as the Godfather...So, yeah, see Drive, I'm sure you'll love it.At it's heart, Drive is a contradiction.  The script is pulled right from late 70's, early 80's action flicks - it's got a very simplistic plot, very simplistic characters (flawless hero?  check.  trophy girl?  check.  muscle villain and brain villain?  check.  wormy sidekick?  check-twice actually!) and was the type of thing that used to get made to showcase awesome spectacle while being stupid fun.  But Drive is also a very modern, slowly paced, art-house film with unique (and weird) visuals, brutal violence, and a downright oppresive soundtrack (I get it, he's a 'real hero, a real human being', turn the music off already).  So what we're left with is an action flick that is just no fun at all.  The tone is so heavy and the violence so brutal and punctuated that the simplistic elements of the script feel hard to swallow.  We don't question Clint Eastwoods man with no name character being good at violence, because everyone in those movies is good at violence and he's just slightly better because he's the good guy and he rules.  But why the hell is this nameless 'Driver', who pointedly doesn't carry a gun and does nothing but drive cars well, so good and efficient at killing?  How come the first (and best) driving scene involves him carefully avoiding the police with skill and subterfuge and the second (and silliest) has him swerving around in broad daylight at high speeds in a world where highway patrol doesn't even seem to exist?  These internal contradictions, not of logic but of STYLE, kept taking me out and would not let me enjoy this movie that seemed to be written for enjoyement but filmed for artistic fulfillment and to make some kind of point about violence.  ...that it's bad?  I'm not sure.  Sometimes it's bad, but sometimes it's awesome?By the way: tangent - the scene in the strip club is amazing and among the best pieces of a movie I've seen in years (and not because fo the nudity, though that never hurts).  It's fluidly paced, the violence is simple and honest and not ridiculous like in the rest of the film, and we see more character there than almost anywhere else.  It's a brilliant, brilliant scene.Moving on, I'd like to come to the crux of the movie and why, I think, many people love it and I do not.  Ladies and gentlemen... Mr. Ryan Goseling.Goseling's talent in the past has been creating specific, unique, emotionally available characters... which is not at all why he's in this movie.  He's in this movie because he's popular right now and because he's gorgeous.  Ten years ago, this movie would have starred Brad Pitt.  Ten years before that, Patrick Swayze.  Before that, Paul Newman, Steve McQueen, et al.  He's the chin du jour, the GQ man of the hour.  It doesn't hurt that he's a good actor, but here he's being used as a blatant 'blank slate' for the audience to project themselves upon.  In the very first scene he's painted as super awesome, super efficient, flawless and nearly invincible - yet he has nearly no facial expression and no real opinions on anything (so you can inject your own).  Guys instantly want to be him. In the second scene, in the grocery store, we see him be meak and awkward around people - especially women (still no real expressions or opinions, again, to not get in the way of the audience injecting their own).  The ladies in the audience instantly imagine themselves as the only person to truly appreciate him, and they want to wrap him up and take him home because no one will ever understand him like they do and blah, blah, blah, sweaty sex fantasy.(I'm making gender generalizations here, and I apologize.  It's just faster.)I could go on for hours about how these two character types don't exist in the same person outside of BS action movies, but it really doesn't matter.  Drive has just delivered the protagonist one-two punch: turned an attactive and popular masturbation fantasy actor into a (potentialy) univerally acceptable blank slate character.  If the movie has you emulating with a character you've created in your own head, you're going the have a good time.  The next 90 minutes just need to be interesting to look at and marginally cohesive.  Which, in all fairness, they are.And this is where Drive failed to grasp me.  I had no interest in projecting anything on the Driver character.  I wanted to see an interesting character study, because the opening scene let me know I wasn't getting a mindless action flick (which, again, is fine - that opening heist scene is amazing).  But I don't get that either... so what do I get?A mediocre flick with good visuals and modest performances that's neither fun nor thought provoking, but one that everyone around me will say is brilliant and unique and timeless and blah blah blah sweaty sex fantasy.  It's not a bad movie, not by any stretch.  But I have a hard time swallowing it as something special.But, yeah, see Drive.  Everyone else likes it and you probably will too.

reviewText: Ryan Gosling overtakes Jason Statham as the stoic man behind the wheel. Like his bald-headed rival he gets into trouble when distracted by a woman and is hurled into a plot involving gangsters and hitmen. While Louis Leterrier's French thriller tried so hard to be Hollywood, Danish director Nicolas Winding Refn's LA-based thriller tries very hard to be European, and takes the viewer on a ride down a lost highway.At the same time it also comes across as a secret remake of Walter Hill's The Driver. All of these films are very, very similar, but Drive is the best of them. It's difficult to comprehensively review the movie as it is very minimalistic and focuses more on atmosphere and the quiet moments in between dialogue rather than action and twists. It's a wonderful movie to look at though, and I do want to complain about how problematic the morals and values of the unnamed 'Driver' are, but if it is the intention to make him morally ambiguous then I guess it is successful. It doesn't make for a great character regardless of how smooth Gosling plays him.The violence is harrowing and brutal, as it is in real life. Nicolas Winding Refn seems to understand that there is no action in real life, there is only violence, and it's brutal and ugly and not something any sane person wants to happen to them. In this respect it is far more grown-up than The Transporter but cannot be praised as being a 'better' film as it is still sold on style and visuals. The substance takes a back seat and the movie apologetically delivers what it wants without feeling the need to scream for attention. I have to respect it for that.Shot in ProRes 4:4:4 the movie looks great in 2.35:1 1080p. The blacks are gorgeous and the daylight scenes look just brilliant. It sounds just as good in DTS HD-MA. reviewText: In this day and age of disposable $100 million films, and films working ridiculously hard on creating not much more than a strong opening weekend, many filmmakers and film audiences forget that like all forms of art, cinema has its own language. What takes five paragraphs to write in a book can be shown in five seconds of a film, and the same works in reverse. Also in this day and age, films tend to get pigeon-holed into three categories; the first two being the most immediately recognizable: The Popcorn-Munchers and The Oscar-Bait. They're easy to recognize.The third are what I refer to as The Dump films. Basically, these are films that will get a wider audience than a limited-release film, but they're generally released in the weakest parts of the year with no expectation of big box-office or great critical acclaim; months like September, most of October, January and February are loaded with Dump Films, so it was no surprise to me that a film like Nicolas Winding Refn's DRIVE was released in September. It was a film with actors rather than stars, and a film that was more of a throwback to the great psuedo-independent crime thrillers of the 1980's (such as MANHUNTER and THIEF, both of those films from Michael Mann who also helped to define TV in the 80's with MIAMI VICE and CRIME STORY, and TO LIVE AND DIE IN L.A. from Mann's fellow Chicagoan William Friedkin) rather than the high-octane FAST AND FURIOUS flash-over-substance film that one very disgruntled audience member thought it would be and took her outrage to unintentionally satirical heights by suing DRIVE's distributor for the cost of her ticket as well as asserting the film also had Anti-Semitic views and still intends to file a class-action suit against "false advertising". I include this anecdote mostly because I think the gall it takes to do something like this is beyond astounding, but also because I believe this woman represents most of the viewing public who saw this film.Looking at the public's reviews of this film, it's very much a love-it-or-hate-it film. Many viewers assail the film for being too slow, too boring, and even in some cases, too graphic. Critical acclaim has been nearly universal for the film. It was one of the best reviewed films of 2011 alongside films like THE ARTIST and THE MUPPETS, but not as successful as either of those films, commercially or Oscar-y. The reason being that DRIVE is not a safe film. There isn't a moment that is antiseptic or commercial. It's not meant for mass consumption, and perhaps that explains its own devisive nature as a film. But DRIVE is not afraid to put some of the onus on the audience and tell us, quietly, to expand our ideas of what a great film is and how not only can a picture be worth a thousand words, but a glance or look can be worth a thousand emotions, and the harshness of a sound can be predicated on the silence that precedes it.Without going too much into plot or character, it's important to give credit where credit is due. Ryan Gosling, the too-dreamy-for-words heartthrob of films like THE NOTEBOOK and CRAZY STUPID LOVE who is also the risk-taker of HALF-NELSON, THE BELIEVER, LARS AND THE REAL GIRL and THE IDES OF MARCH, is perfect as the nameless super-anti-hero of the piece. Every look, every glance, every gesture has purpose. The greatest acting talents are the performers who can speak volumes just by saying nothing at all, and this film is loaded with those performers. I call Gosling's character a super-anti-hero because there is something superhuman about this character. He can do just about anything he wants physically, and he can survive just about any assault, except for the emotional. And that's where Carey Mulligan comes in. Mulligan is by far one of the greatest young actors out there. She first really showed us that in AN EDUCATION, and continued to show it in NEVER LET ME GO, SHAME, and this film. She is picture-perfect innocence. You want to protect her, and you understand The Driver's urge to do so. Bryan Cranston, with the introduction of BREAKING BAD a few years ago, has been a revelatory performer. Who knew the dad on MALCOLM IN THE MIDDLE would be one of TV's best serious actors? Not me. And his performance as the other half of the partnership with Gosling is small yet shining. Oscar Isaac as the doomed husband of Mulligan's character plays his ex-con with an immediacy and desperation and sense of inevitability. Ron Perlman as the small-time thug with delusions of grandeur is just pitch-perfect, proving once again that Perlman is a seriously underrated actor. Christina Hendricks is sultry, sexy and that's really all her role requires, which is sad, because I love her. However, the film, from a performance standout, belongs to Albert Brooks. We're used to Brooks playing the nebbish, awkward yet smarter-than-you character. We've seen it since MODERN ROMANCE, and through LOST IN AMERICA, BROADCAST NEWS and others. For Brooks to turn that image on its head and play the lethally efficient and pragmatically violent small-time crime boss Bernie Rose is beyond inspired casting, and the performance he turns in is as strong and chilling as seeing someone like Pacino or De Niro play a similar role. He was nominated for a Golden Globe for Best Supporting Actor but not for an Oscar. In fact, infuriatingly, DRIVE was only nominated for one Academy Award: Best Sound Editing, which if you watch the film closely, it REALLY deserves, but it lost to... whatever; probably TRANSFORMERS or something.The other shining star of this film is director Nicolas Winding Refn. Being somewhat unfamiliar with his work prior to this film, I tried to watch the ultra-surreal BRONSON with Tom Hardy, and couldn't get through it from a narrative standpoint but appreciated its bravura. I haven't seen his other film, VALHALLA RISING yet, but plan to watch it very soon. It's probably more his film than any of the performers: His use of every element of the language of cinema is so deftly handled, from the sound to the picture to the editing to the performers, he achieves cinematic perfection. The film works on every level it's supposed to: Crime Thriller, Fairy-Tale Romance, Emotional Drama, Anti-Heroic Action, it does it all flawlessly. Another unsung hero of this film is Cliff Martinez, who does the Tangerine Dream-esque score for the film as another nod to those classic 80's thrillers.The simple fact of DRIVE is that this film was the purest expression of the language of cinema that came out of 2011. It never missed a moment to capitalize on that language, and it speaks it fluently and perfectly. This is, hands down, the best film of 2011.
