reviewText: In order to really appreciate DRIVE, you have to throw the general formulas for scripts that you're used to out the window.There isn't very much dialog in this movie, or at least for the first 20 minutes, but there are definitely lots of pregnant pauses. At first it seems a bit awkward that Ryan Gosling's character doesn't say much, but I learned to really appreciate the silence in the movie. It gave the movie a definite "cool" factor. It really helped to build the intrigue of the character and it added to the suspense. I found myself hanging on every word and body movement, which was really refreshing and it kept me on the edge of my seat. In a world of movies and TV shows with non-stop mindless chatter and jabbering, DRIVE was a breath of fresh air.Without giving too much away, this movie is a cross between the action scenes of "Transporter", the mob/gangster storyline of "Departed", and the darkness of Donnie Darko (because the lead character was a bit strange in that movie, too). The music sounds a bit "80's-esque" as well, which was when the setting of Donnie Darko took place.But with those slight comparisons aside, it's a unique movie with incredible style. The acting is superb, the music is awesome, and the script is well-written. Some people complain it's too slow. It's true that there aren't many "action scenes", but neither did the Godfather movies. Trust me, I have a short attention span like every other red blooded American, however, the movie never seemed to lag or get boring. There was always at least one plot line that kept up the suspense level.I don't typically buy movies because I really don't like re-watching something I recently saw, but I loved this one enough to pre-order it so I can watch it again and again.

reviewText: A ton of love and hate for this film, but I went in undeterred to see if Ryan Gosling could finally be in a worthy Blu Ray - and I discovered he found his way onto a great product preservation here.The story follows the "driver with a code" formula who falls in love with a lady and does things to mess with the code (actually that summary is virtually taken from the producers of the film, they themselves admitting there was nothing different about this film - except for how it was filmed). The Blu quality is amazing, and depending on the scene it will be testing your blacks and dark motion sensitivity to the extreme. There are two LA skyline night shots that are worthy of pausing and looking for detail clarity. Several other shots with different cameras are almost Michael Mann-ish in their grain and coloring, but so is a lot of this film. The sound is a mixed bag - beautiful yet possibly dangerous depending how high you might be cranking it up to hear the center channel subtleties laced for 15 minutes - followed unexpectedly with a flood of high pitches/decibel increase (follow the hints with the music - when it starts to fade or the lights are coming back to brightness after fading - quick turn it back down before your center gets blown). The DTS is great in the two main chase sequences and the motors were overamped just right.The special features are definitely a mixed bag:* Cut to the Chase, 4:35 minutes. Listed it first because this was the one I had the most interest in...specifically how they pulled off that reverse 270 with the actress in the shot. Unfortunately this was way too short and only glossed over what should have been a 30 minute piece on the stunts...worthy enough though to discover that sequence was not CGI.* Driver & Irene, 6:14 minutes. This and the next two are so clip-heavy they provide so little substance - all forgettable. This one follows the love story angle with talking heads and clips.* Under the Hood, 11:50 minutes. Not what I had hoped as I was looking for car and motor info. Instead it is an extremely clip-heavy talking head piece about the actors and their takes on characters.* I Drive, 5:26 minutes. A confused quip that looks like it was cut from the the prior segment about actors working with the director.* Drive without the Driver, 25:41 minutes. Wow, I cannot think of a more boring way to get all of the information that leads up to the film being made, how it was cast, and so forth. The director (who I respect from his prior work - he assuredly has an eye for filming) sits on a hood of a car and rambles for 25 minutes about the process, essentially a commentary - but as an interview. If you are fans of commentaries (which I am) then you will dig this segment - otherwise a skipper.Overall a fascinating look at a performance film preserved on a solid Blu that has a great picture quality and test-worthy sound, the supplements ding this from being a five but there are no half-stars here...4 for the film and BD specs, .5 star for the supplements.

reviewText: POSSIBLE LIGHT SPOILERS BELOW:It's funny, people I know who've seen "Drive" either love it or absolutely hate it. I fell in love with it in its first five minutes. The movie isn't an action packed extravaganza dripping with testosterone but the opening sequence where the unnamed driver (Ryan Gosling) does his thing as a freelance getaway driver is one of the best openings to a film ever and really helps to sell you on the character and the world he inhabits.I really can't explain what it is about the film that I love so much but there's something about the mood that this film creates and revels in that just wrapped me in its arms and never let me go until the credits started rolling. The music especially makes you feel like you're watching something that would've fit perfectly amidst the roster of films released in the mid to late 80's. It's a haunting film, filled with haunting performances by many fine actors, including Carey Mulligan, Bryan Cranston, Ron Perlman, Oscar Issac, Christina Hendricks and most surprisingly, Albert Brooks. Trust me, after watching this film, you'll never look at Mr. Brooks the same way again as he plays a character way against type in this film. Ryan Gosling has managed to make me a fan based on this film alone, the only thing I've seen him in as of yet. If you like Gosling, I think it's safe to say you'll like him in this as his character is truly a likable fellow, even if he is a little unhinged.In terms of the technical details, this is a fine looking Blu-Ray that sounds pretty fantastic when it needs to. For example, during the aforementioned chase scene there's a helicopter flyover that just fills up the sound stage, making you feel like there's one hovering a few feet above you. This isn't a movie filled with gunfire and explosions but the surround sound is used to great effect, adding an extra dimension to the music and ambiance of the film that is already in place. The extras are okay, with the best feature of the bunch being an interview with director Nicholas Winding Refn, who goes on at length to talk about many of the facets of the production and how the film came about. It's a very interesting discussion, especially if you're a fan of the film."Drive" has become one of my absolute favorite films of the past year. I can't even tell you how many times I've seen it since I initially watched it. If you haven't seen it, I say give it a shot. Just don't go in expecting a non-stop action film and take it for what it's worth and I think you'll appreciate it. If you've already seen it and you're interested in picking up the Blu, I feel comfortable in recommending it. I kind of wish it had a little bit more in the special features department but all in all, it's a solid presentation of a pretty solid film.

reviewText: I heard a lot about this film before I saw it.  It raised my expectations and that wasn't a good thing in this case.  The film is a slow boil thriller with sudden and brutal snapshots of gory violence, both exploitative while still remaining grounded, and allows star Ryan Gosling's character "the driver" to mull about quietly and unnervingly a woman and child whose husband/daddy is in jail.  His character is less enigmatic than an enigma.  He's an anti-hero cast in the mold of Clint Eastwood's the man with no name drifter.Solid support is given by the remainder of the cast especially Albert Brooks playing against type as a Mafioso.  Bryan Cranston, the "Breaking Bad" man who is popping up everywhere these days, plays the been-around-the-block touchstone for all of the characters to tie around; the limp is his affectation and limitation, letting us know that he's learned his lessons the hard way but also that he can't quite leave completely the life that doles them out.  Carey Mulligan plays the lady in need of saving, and while her attraction to the driver is palpable the film plays coy and never lets us know how far they've taken their relationship to with each other."Drive" will stay with you for awhile.  It's quiet will drive into your memory and its stark unfolding and unflinching violence will make you wince and want to forget.  But don't expect a cinematic epiphany.  3.75 stars.

He did not have a lot of lines, however, and you could tell that was partially character - motivated and partially mood driven. In some instances this was nice, like in the middle of some action, and some scenes it made a little stale - like sitting around and watching characters not say much. It reminded me of an arthouse film in that respect, relying on expressions given and other mood or familiarity to say things. I'm not sure everyone will enjoy that. There were also other impressive cast members and they did their part as well, making characters that were not unique but that were good enough, illustrating who was a good guy and a bad guy and all the flavors in-between. I'm not saying these are great in any scope, but they pass the bar - even if most of them feel rather shallow. enter Ron Pearlman, yell yell yell. Bad guy, money, anger. You get the idea. It didn't blow me away or anything.The movie itself, once going, was nice to watch. We get some solid effects in the gore department, which I enjoyed a lot, and we get some impressive wheel play. The opening sequence made me think we were going to get going soon, too, but it took some time to set all the pieces. Again, not bad, just something to note. We also get a lot of build into the who and what of the story, fleshing it out a bit. The problem, in some ways, is the amount of time devoted to making a lot of the character bonds develop, and what exactly happens between them. Normally,w hen an hour is devoted to forging a connection, I can feel it. The problem here was the dialog in some respects and possibly some of the choices the movie made in what happened after-the-fact.I'm not saying it was not good, i enjoyed it. I thought it was a solid 4 out of 5, and that a lot of people would like it. That said, some will take exception and not like it for these, and other, reasons. On a day when I wanted what the movie seemed to promise, a thrill ride, I might have been disappointed too. reviewText: **This review may contain spoilers**'Drive' is directed by Nicholas Winding Refn, a Danish director known for films with a violent bent. 'Drive' is no exception, as it emulates some of the darker film noirs of the 40s and 50s as well as the neo-noirs of later years. Refn shot 'Drive' in a contemporary Los Angeles but due to the use of an 80s, synth pop score, the story feels like it's more from the 80s rather than today (sounds like some of those synth tracks with the choppy bass parts were 'borrowed' from one of Hall and Oates' more popular hits).For women who might be drawn to the film due to the casting of Ryan ('The Hunk') Gosling in the lead role, be forewarned that 'Drive' is anything but a 'chick flick'. Gosling, in an unnamed part, moonlights as a getaway driver but has more respectable jobs as a part-time stunt driver and auto mechanic. Unfortunately, Gosling has little dialogue and speaks mostly in a monotone. Even worse is Carey Mulligan who plays Irene, the Driver's next door neighbor and mother of a five year old, who appears to drift about in a perpetual stupor (I seem to recall that when Driver crushes the hit man's head in the elevator, Irene backs off in shock but later never discusses or alludes to the incident at all).Things pick up in terms of action when Irene's husband, Standard, is released from prison but is being forced to commit another robbery by a brute named Cook, who claims Standard still owes a debt to former inmate associates who 'protected' him while incarcerated. A normal guy might feel some jealousy when another man encroaches on his territory, but 'Knight-in-Shining Armor' Gosling is ready to help Standard simply because he's taken a real liking to Irene and the kid.'Drive' soon begins to shine through some neat twists and turns in the plot as well as the introduction of cool supporting players who overshadow both Mr. Gosling and Ms. Mulligan. Some critics have argued that the violence in 'Drive' is gratuitous, but I beg to differ. It might be a bit over the top, but is never cartoonish. In fact, the violence underscores the menacing, ruthless character of the antagonists Gosling's Driver must face.Cook beats Standard to a bloody pulp and the shocks are just beginning. There's the big double cross at the pawn shop, where Standard is shot in the back and later Cook's moll, Blanche, is gunned down at the motel room (there was a significant gasp that could be heard throughout the theater from a taken aback audience when the moll is dispatched). Gosling also gets the chance to be ruthless when he works Cook over. Later Bernie (a mobster played by Albert Brooks, who earlier backed the Driver and Shannon, the owner of the auto body shop where the Driver worked, in a joint stock car racing venture) kills Cook by stabbing him in the face. In addition to the aforementioned 'stomping in the elevator' scene, Bernie eliminates Shannon 'mercifully' by slicing his artery, causing the Driver's former pal, to slowly bleed to death.Who would have thought that comedian Albert Brooks, could actually be so good as an amoral crime boss? Bryan Cranston is also excellent as the Driver's seedy employer. Ron Perlman is always great playing the heavy but I would have liked to have seen more of him, as his character Nino's declaration of his Jewishness, remains wholly underdeveloped.The film's climax, where the Driver cuts off Nino's car on the highway, leading to his death by drowning at the hands of the Driver, was quite exciting. Less exciting and more awkward was the Driver's agreement to meet Bernie in public and return the money. For a person as crafty as the driver, didn't he anticipate that Bernie would try and hurt him at the scene of their meeting place? Or is it that he just didn't care? One other thing I wondered about at film's end. If the loot belonged to the east coast Mafia, even though Bernie and Nino were now dead, wouldn't the Mafioso still come looking for the Driver as well as Irene, who they would have discovered was affiliated with him? Thus, how could the Driver ride off into the sunset, knowing full well that Irene was still vulnerable?When I saw the title 'Drive', I expected the film to have many more chase scenes. Fortunately, director Refn took the story in a different direction, emphasizing the rivalry between the Driver and his criminal antagonists. 'Drive' is a film which doesn't have a lot to say. In other words, if you're looking for great 'meaning', you will not find it here. With the exception of the more complex Bernie, its characters are pretty much one-dimensional caricatures, especially the main protagonists, played by Gosling and Mulligan. Nonetheless, in the tradition of some of the great noirs and neo-noirs of the past, 'Drive' manages to be highly entertaining, due to a dynamic plot, that will keep you on the edge of your seat.
summary: Dynamic and entertaining neo-noir plot trumps Gosling and Mulligan wooden parts and performances

reviewText: This movie is a film school graduate's mishmash of 1980s noirish film styles and attitudes. This throwback offers jagged titles, electronic music, and stylized, Michael Mann-like direction. The carefully lit, composed shots of Gosling looking sullen and tough is an obvious homage to James Dean. What's missing is originality, a unique vision, real drama, and the desire to be anything more than a good-looking, magazine cover-worthy movie. This is a hipster's idea of cool - derivative, shamelessly nostalgic, an appeal for edginess within the safe and familiar, and an infatuation with designer clothing. We all know, from Gosling's first appearance, that he's a handsome bad boy who will be doomed by falling in love, and everything in-between is just a lot of filler violence until that happens. Gosling is also miscast - to make this pretty boy seem tougher than he is, he dons a fright mask and refuses to say more than a few words (like a hipster in a bad neighborhood). The only thing I'd use this movie for is to collect freeze frame shots of Gosling's gorgeous face and hang them up on a wall. It's also a boon to makers of shiny satin jackets with dragons on the backs of them (Shopaholics start your engines). But if you're expecting something more than a fashion photo spread dressed up as a movie, look elsewhere.

reviewText: Nicolas Winding Refn's "Drive" is a minimalist love letter to films like Michael Mann's "Thief" and William Friedkin's "To Live and Die in L.A." from the use of pulsating sythesizer music to score the film to riveting action sequences alternating with long, drawn out scenes of the Driver (Ryan Gosling) doing exactly what he's best at--driving getaway cars, Hollywood stunt vehicles. Keep in mind that "Drive" although it echoes things like the titles from a film like "Thief", "To Live and Die in L.A." (a William Friedkin film) and "Manhunter" in terms of its soundtrack, titles, asthetics, etc., is an indie film with a distinctive European art house flavor.SPOILERS:The Driver has a specific code for right and wrong that he lives by. Moving out of his isolated world the Driver falls for Irene (Carey Mulligan)a married woman who's ex-con husband Standard (Oscar Issac)ends up spelling trouble when the Driver in an attempt to help Irene acts as a driver for one last job to liberate Irene and her family.END OF SPOILERS"Drive" is minimalist in every sense of the word from the sparse dialog to the straight forward emotional connection that the Driver develops with those around him from Irene to his employer and friend Shannon (Bryan Cranston). Featuring a terrific supporting cast (Albert Brooks in an unexpected turn as a bad guy, Ron Perlman, Christina Hendricks in what amounts to a cameo), "Drive" won't be for everyone but those who like the unusual mixture of genre action films mixed with art films that Mann helped pioneer back in the 1980's will enjoy this retro thriller.The DVD looks positively stunning with a nice, sharp transfer. Colors vary a bit from the cool surfaces of the night photography to the warmer skin tones during the day sequences of the film. Detail is extremely good throughout with nice skin textures and a fair amount of grain that compliments the gritty feeling of the film.Audio positively pops and pulsates particularly during the action sequences or those where the Driver is cruising the city.Special features include "I Drive" which focuses on the inspiration for the film, "Under the Hood" focusing on the cars, "Driver and Irene" on the pivotal relationship in the film and a nice long interview with director Refn where he discusses his fetish for cars (although he and screenwriter Hossini Amini don't drive)to the genesis of the film (high on medication for a nasty flu bug after a horrible meeting with Gosling Refn was inspired to come up with the basic plot for "Drive" when Gosling drove him back to his hotel and that basic outline was incorporated into the script that Amini adapted from James Sallis book).It's a bit disappointing that we don't get an audio commentary and the film comes with the dreaded (by many) Ultraviolet copy that you have to stream live on your portable device but, those two minor drawbacks aside, "Drive" is a fascinating combination of 80's retro filmmaking.If the description doesn't sound like it will appeal to you, I'd suggest renting before buying.
summary: An indie minimalist love letter to 80's films like Michael Mann's "Thief" with distinctive European flavor

reviewText: [There are no spoilers here. Just the cold, hard facts of a wonderful movie]"Drive" is a pleasure in so many ways. First, it has lots of action but, unlike the subpar "Fast & Furious" movies, there is actual character development in this movie. Many action films, especially in the 21st century, have abandoned character development completely in favor of non-stop CGI effects, 1-second shots before cutting to the next 1-second shot, and little or no reason for the existence of a plot."Drive" is an action movie that does not have those 21st century movie cliches and if you expect to see anything like what I mentioned above, then feel free to go and rent or buy a Fast & Furious movie. For the people who deny this is an action movie [by saying its too slow in the middle] are not appreciating or realizing that even the best action movies cannot be 100% action. There has to be character development.The main character ("Driver") is a complex individual who doesn't say much and doesn't have to. He is a man of action and there's no better lead character to have in an action movie than a man of action. "Driver" doesn't talk the talk, "Driver" walks the walk. He talks when only absolutely necessary and, when things go haywire, "Driver" is not your cardboard action hero who is "made of stone." This guy has feelings and can be nervous just like the toughest of the toughest human beings. He has great love, admiration, and respect for people who deserve it and will dish out the revenge needed to anyone who harms either him or the ones he cares for.The soundtrack to the film is unique to any action film. The instrumental music and pink-colored credits reminded me of those great 1980s action movies like William Friedkin's "To Live and Die in L.A." and Michael Mann's "Thief" - 2 of the greatest action/drama flicks of all time. They had plot, action, and character development just like "Drive."This movie gave me hope for future action movies: that movie makers will go back to making good action-packed movies without all of the horrible movie cliches that have plagued recent action films for the last decade."Driver" knows how to get things done, knows how to show people a good time, and knows how to survive and provide for himself in this dog-eat-dog world. He reminds me a little bit of the Charles Bronson character (Arthur Bishop) in "The Mechanic" - a man who was great at what he does and was not afraid to do whatever was necessary in order to survive and protect himself.A real hero...a real human being...a fantastic movie.
